text: I have my own uh Theory which
undoubtedly is not correct but uh it is
that the um that the the New Deal was a
such a radical break from what America
was all about um you know Rexford
tugwell one of the intellectuals of the
New Deal um said that it took quote uh a
tortured interpretation of a document
meant to prevent it uh for the New Deal
to be created and uh that document that
was tortured was the US
Constitution and it was Hayek would have
said the same thing there's going to be
a reaction to such a radical departure
from where the country had gone for its
entire existence until this kind of
misunderstood Great Depression which was
blamed on Lifey Affair capitalism and
was in fact a function of the smooth
Holly tariffs and the manipulation of
the money supply and credit availability
uh by the federal government um so um
you had these laws passed that created
this giant federal government but it's
interesting that if you consider uh uh
the defeat of Stevenson in 62 as the end
of the new deal or 52
um within 10 years the number one
political book in America was the
conscience of a conservative by Barry
Goldwater and that was America saying
you know what because that book is just
a repudiation of the new
deal and I think that you know the
goldwater's campaign uh LED you got 26
million votes there was a bumper sticker
that said 26 million Americans can't be
wrong and but that was you know he lost
big time but it was a a major statement
about what had happened in the previous
years
and then um and then uh Reagan got Fame
because of the speech he gave on behalf
of Goldwater and he was elected in 1980
almost got the nomination in
76 he certainly was governor of
California as a result of of the speech
he gave for uh Goldwater I guess in ' 68
he got elected governor
California but uh and that was a
movement uh to uh to reestablish the
limited government regime and it did
pretty well I mean go Reagan did well uh
until 82 when he kind of backtracked on
taxes and and Marty Anderson left the
administration but uh the worst thing
that Reagan did in in my view was in
1984 when he was enormously popular he'd
been shot and made jokes you know in the
face of death and and uh people just
loved him they they and the economy came
back because the tax cuts and everything
uh he should have run a campaign saying
look we're going to privatize Social
Security uh we're going to get rid of
these agencies that are not any uh
concern of the federal government and
and he would have won he would would he
have won 49 states no but he would have
won 40 States and instead he ran this
morning America campaign and I think
that was a terrible mistake it was there
was no substance to it he had no mandate
once he was elected and the other
mistake that uh Reagan made was to uh uh
to give the nod to George HW Bush I mean
Reagan had uh lunch with him once a week
for eight years and if he couldn't tell
that that guy had not an ideological
bone in his body that was Reagan's fault
and Bush was contemptuous of the what he
called the the vision thing um he fired
every single Reagan appointee when he
got into office and uh and that was the
beginning of the slide downhill I think
and then there's a great U Nobel laurat
Economist at George Mason James panon
who uh lamented the rise of uh the
supply side Revolution because he said
and I agree with him that what they have
done uh the supply Siders you know
really became dominant in people like
Jude winsky and Jack Kemp and art
laugher in the um in the late 80s and
90s and their whole thing was growth
they were going to shrink the government
as a percentage of GDP not by cutting
government but by cutting taxes and
growing the economy faster than
government could grow and and Buchanan
made the point that you know you you
can't stop talking about what limited
government's about and these guys have
replaced uh Liberty with growth and I
think that that happened to the
Republican party and that is you know
this long-winded answer to your question
but I think that's part of what happened
that uh and he said furthermore there's
going to be an ideological vacuum
created if you don't talk about limited
government and while the supply Siders
are well-meaning and most of the ones I
know believe in limited government their
explicit strategy was um uh we're not
going to talk about spending cuts we're
not going to talk about the proper Ru of
government we're just going to talk
about economic growth and that is a
function of lower taxes because
incentives matter well I agree that
incentives matter and lower taxes are a
good thing but I also know that you have
to you have to make a principled case
for limited government and that vacuum I
believe has been filled with the neocons
who are openly uh forbid government not
just everyone says well you know they
have this horrible
approach to policing the world and and
telling everybody how to you know that
we're going to have American Empire and
that's true but they're also very big on

Irving Crystal had a article in his

criticized Hayak criticized Barry
Goldwater lauded
FDR uh this is the neocon approach and
they're very very influential No Child
Left Behind in the Bush Administration
which is basically a federal takeover of
education is their initiative the
faith-based initiative getting the
government involved in funding religious
organizations is a neocon initiative and
just the whole concept of national
greatness that that we can't be a great
country just by being free no we have to
have some project to go to Mars or
whatever and or build a tunnel from New
York to London uh the these are to me
very uh
unamerican kinds of initiatives so we
